gurmukhi: Dwie pry kr kop qbY Bt dY muK Fwl ley krvwrY ] swmuih Awie hTI hiT isau Gin sXwm khwN ieh BwNq hkwrY ]
transliteration: Dhaae Dare Kar Kop Tabai Bhat Dai Moukh Dhaal Lae Karvdarai|| Saamuh(i) Aae Hathee(i) Sio Ghan(i) Syaam Eh Bhaant Hakdarai||
translation: The warriors getting enraged, taking up the swords and shields in their hands fell upon Krishna, who challenged them and they persistently came in front of him;

gurmukhi: mUsl c`kR gdw gih kY su hqY hir kOc auTY icngwrY ] mwno luhwr lIey Gn hwQn loh kryry ko kwm svwrY ]1771]
transliteration: Moondal Chakkra Gadaa Gadh Kai Su Hatai Har(i) Kaouch Outhai Chingdarai|| Maano Luhaar Leee Ghan Haathan Loh Kadere Ko Kaam Svdarai||1771||
translation: On this side, Krishna, catching hold of his club, discus, mace etc. in his hands, struck terrible blows and the sparks emanated from the armours; it appeared that an ironsmith was fashioning according to his desire the iron by the strokes of his hammer.17

gurmukhi: qau lg hI brmw kiRq aUDv Awie hY sXwm shwie ky kwrn ] Aaur AkRUr ley sMg jwdv Dwie prXo Air bIr ibdwrn ]
transliteration: Tau Lag Hibarmaa Krit Oodhav Aae Hai Syaam Sahaae Ke Kaaran|| Aur Akroor Lae San Jaadav Dhaae Daryo Ar(i) Beer Bidaaran||
translation: Till that time, Kratvarma and Uddhava reached for the help of Krishna; Akrur also taking the Yadava warriors with him fell upon the enemies in order to kill them;

gurmukhi: SsqR sMBwr sBY Apuny kib sXwm khY muK mwr aucwrn ] Er duhU Aiq ju`Du BXo su gdw brCI krvwr ktwrn ]1772]
transliteration: Shastra Sanbhaar Sabhai Apnoune Kabi Syaam Kahai Moukh Maar Ouchaaran|| Or Duhoo At(i) Juddh(u) Bhayo Su Gadaa Barchhikarvaar Kataaran||1772||
translation: Holding their weapons and should “kill, kill”, a dreadful war was waged from both sides with maces, lances swords, daggers etc.1772.

gurmukhi: Awvq hI brmw kiRq jU Aru sYn huqy su Gny Bt kUty ] eyk pry ibb KMfq hI Aru eyk igry Dr pY isr PUt ]
transliteration: Oovat Hibarmaa Krit Joo Ar(u) Sain Houte Su Ghane Bhat Koogte Koote|| Ek Dare Bib Khandat Hiar(u) Ek Gire Dhar Pai Sir Phoote||
translation: Kratvarma on coming chopped down many warriors; someone has been cut into two parts and someone’s head has been cut down;

gurmukhi: eyk mhw blvwn kmwnn qwn clwvq ieau sr CUty ] kwj bsyry ky rYn smY miDAwn mno qr pY Kg tUty ]1773]
transliteration: Ek Mahaa Balvaan Kamaanan Taan Chadaavat Io Sar Chhodhte|| Kaaj Badere Ke Rain Samai Madhiaan Mano Tar Pai Khag Toote||1773||
translation: From the bows of several powerful warriors the arrows are being discharged in this way that it seems the birds are flying groups towards the trees for rest in the evening before the night falls.1773.

gurmukhi: eyk kbMD lIey krvwr iPrY rn BUm ky BIqr folq ] Dwie prY iqh Er blI Bt jo iqh ko llkwr kY bolq ]
transliteration: Ek Kabandh Leee Karvaar Phirai Ran Bhoom Ke Bheetar Dolat|| Dhaae Darai Tih Or Balibhat Jo Tih Ko Lalkaar Kai Dolat||
translation: Somewhere the headless trunks are roaming in the battlefield taking the swords in their hands and whosoever challenging in the field, the warriors fall upon him;

gurmukhi: eyk pry igr pwie kty auTby khu bwhin ko bl qolq ] eyk kt Buj XoN qrpY jl hIn ijau mIn pirE JkJolq ]1774]
transliteration: Ek Dare Gir Paae Kate Outhhe Kauh Baahan(i) Ko Bal Dolat|| Ek Katibhuj Yon Tarpai Jal Been Jio Meen Pario Jhak-jdolat||1774||
translation: Someone has fallen because his foot has been cut and for getting up, he is taking the support of the vehicle and somewhere the chopped arm is writhing like a fish out of water.1774.

gurmukhi: eyk kbMD ibnw hiQXwrn rwm khY rn BUm mY daurY ] suMfn qyg jrwjn ko gih kY kir kY bl so JkJorY ]
transliteration: Ek Kabandh Binaa Hathiyaaran Raam Kahai Ran Bhoom Mai Dauri|| Sounddan Teg Jaraajan Ko Gadh Kai Kar(i) Kai Bal So Jhak-jhorai||
translation: The poet Ram says that some headless trunk is running in the battlefield without the weapon and catching hold of the trunks of the elephants, is shaking them violently with force;

gurmukhi: BUm igry miRq AsÍn kI duhUM hwQn so gih gRIv mrorY ] sXMdn kY Asvwrn ky isr eyk cpyt hI ky sMg qorY ]1775]
transliteration: Bhoom Gire Mrit Asvan Kiasvaaran Ke Sir Ek Chapet Hike San Torai||1775||
translation: He is also pulling the neck of dead horses lying on the ground with both his hands and is trying to break the heads of the dead horse-riders with one slap.1775.
